mn139:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn139:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn139:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn139:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I shall teach you the analysis of no strife.
mn139:2.1.comm: Rig Vedic raṇa usually means “joy, delight” (eg. 8.96.16, 10.104.7) or occasionally “war, strife” (6.15.5, 10.112.10, 10.113.4). | See note on MN 137:2.1.

mn139:2.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn139:2.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn139:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

mn139:3.1.pli: “Na kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya hīnaṃ gammaṃ pothujjanikaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, na ca attakilamathānuyogamanuyuñjeyya dukkhaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ.
mn139:3.1.eng: “Don’t indulge in sensual pleasure, which is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.
mn139:3.1.comm: This is adapted from the first sermon; text has kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya which is a briefer expression that the original kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogo at SN 56.11:2.3.

mn139:3.2.pli: Ete kho, bhikkhave, ubho ante anupagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
mn139:3.2.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One understood the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.

mn139:3.3.eng: Know what it means to flatter and to rebuke.

mn139:3.4.pli: ussādanañca ñatvā apasādanañca ñatvā nevussādeyya, na apasādeyya, dhammameva deseyya.
mn139:3.4.eng: Knowing these, avoid them, and just teach Dhamma.

mn139:3.5.eng: Know how to evaluate different kinds of pleasure.

mn139:3.7.pli: Rahovādaṃ na bhāseyya, sammukhā na khīṇaṃ bhaṇe.
mn139:3.7.eng: Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.

mn139:3.9.eng: Don’t insist on popular definitions and don’t overstep normal labels.
mn139:3.9.comm: “Popular definitions” is janapadanirutti. | Samaññā (“label”, Sanskrit samājñā) ought not be confused with sāmañña (“agreement”, “equality”, Sanskrit sāmānya).

mn139:3.10.eng: This is the summary recital for the analysis of no strife.

mn139:4.1.pli: ‘Na kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya hīnaṃ gammaṃ pothujjanikaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, na ca attakilamathānuyogamanuyuñjeyya dukkhaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitan’ti—
mn139:4.1.eng: ‘Don’t indulge in sensual pleasure, which is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.’

mn139:4.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ; Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn139:4.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn139:4.3.pli: Yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogo hīno gammo pothujjaniko anariyo anatthasaṃhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; micchāpaṭipadā.
mn139:4.3.eng: Indulging in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:4.4.pli: Yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṃ ananuyogo hīnaṃ gammaṃ pothujjanikaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; sammāpaṭipadā.
mn139:4.4.eng: Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.

mn139:4.5.pli: Yo attakilamathānuyogo dukkho anariyo anatthasaṃhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; micchāpaṭipadā.
mn139:4.5.eng: Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:4.6.pli: Yo attakilamathānuyogaṃ ananuyogo dukkhaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; sammāpaṭipadā.
mn139:4.6.eng: Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.

mn139:4.7.pli: ‘Na kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya hīnaṃ gammaṃ pothujjanikaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, na ca attakilamathānuyogaṃ anuyuñjeyya dukkhaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitan’ti—
mn139:4.7.eng: ‘Don’t indulge in sensual pleasure, which is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.’

mn139:4.8.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn139:4.8.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn139:5.1.pli: ‘Ete kho ubho ante anupagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattatī’ti—
mn139:5.1.eng: ‘Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One understood the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.’

mn139:5.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn139:5.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn139:5.3.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

mn139:5.4.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
mn139:5.4.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

mn139:5.5.pli: ‘Ete kho ubho ante anupagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattatī’ti—
mn139:5.5.eng: ‘Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One understood the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.’

mn139:5.6.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn139:5.6.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn139:6.1.eng: ‘Know what it means to flatter and to rebuke.

mn139:6.2.pli: ussādanañca ñatvā apasādanañca ñatvā nevussādeyya, na apasādeyya, dhammameva deseyyā’ti—
mn139:6.2.eng: Knowing these, avoid them, and just teach Dhamma.’

mn139:6.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn139:6.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn139:7.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, ussādanā ca hoti apasādanā ca, no ca dhammadesanā?
mn139:7.1.eng: And how is there flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma?

mn139:7.2.pli: ‘Ye kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṃ anuyuttā hīnaṃ gammaṃ pothujjanikaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:7.2.eng: ‘All those who indulge in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality—low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless—are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’

mn139:7.3.eng: In speaking like this, one rebukes some here.

mn139:7.4.pli: ‘Ye kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṃ ananuyuttā hīnaṃ gammaṃ pothujjanikaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:7.4.eng: ‘All those who have broken off indulging in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’

mn139:7.5.eng: In speaking like this, one flatters some here.

mn139:7.6.pli: ‘Ye attakilamathānuyogaṃ anuyuttā dukkhaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:7.6.eng: ‘All those who indulge in self-mortification—painful, ignoble, and pointless—are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’

mn139:7.7.eng: In speaking like this, one rebukes some here.

mn139:7.8.pli: ‘Ye attakilamathānuyogaṃ ananuyuttā dukkhaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:7.8.eng: ‘All those who have broken off indulging in self-mortification are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’

mn139:7.9.eng: In speaking like this, one flatters some here.

mn139:7.10.pli: ‘Yesaṃ kesañci bhavasaṃyojanaṃ appahīnaṃ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:7.10.eng: ‘All those who have not given up the fetter of continued existence are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’

mn139:7.11.eng: In speaking like this, one rebukes some here.

mn139:7.12.pli: ‘Yesaṃ kesañci bhavasaṃyojanaṃ pahīnaṃ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:7.12.eng: ‘All those who have given up the fetter of continued existence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’

mn139:7.13.eng: In speaking like this, one flatters some here.

mn139:7.14.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ussādanā ca hoti apasādanā ca, no ca dhammadesanā.
mn139:7.14.eng: That’s how there is flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma.

mn139:8.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, nevussādanā hoti na apasādanā, dhammadesanā ca?
mn139:8.1.eng: And how is there neither flattering nor rebuking, and just teaching Dhamma?

mn139:8.2.pli: ‘Ye kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṃ anuyuttā hīnaṃ gammaṃ pothujjanikaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:8.2.eng: You don’t say: ‘All those who indulge in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality—low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless—are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’

mn139:8.3.eng: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:

mn139:8.4.pli: ‘Anuyogo ca kho sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:8.4.eng: ‘The indulgence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.’

mn139:8.7.pli: ‘Ye kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṃ ananuyuttā hīnaṃ gammaṃ pothujjanikaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:8.7.eng: You don’t say: ‘All those who have broken off indulging in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’

mn139:8.8.eng: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:

mn139:8.9.pli: ‘Ananuyogo ca kho adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
mn139:8.9.eng: ‘Breaking off the indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.’

mn139:8.12.pli: ‘Ye attakilamathānuyogaṃ anuyuttā dukkhaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:8.12.eng: You don’t say: ‘All those who indulge in self-mortification—painful, ignoble, and pointless—are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’

mn139:8.13.eng: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:

mn139:8.14.pli: ‘Anuyogo ca kho sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:8.14.eng: ‘The indulgence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.’

mn139:8.17.pli: ‘Ye attakilamathānuyogaṃ ananuyuttā dukkhaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:8.17.eng: You don’t say: ‘All those who have broken off indulging in self-mortification are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’

mn139:8.18.eng: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:

mn139:8.19.pli: ‘Ananuyogo ca kho adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
mn139:8.19.eng: ‘Breaking off the indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.’

mn139:8.22.pli: ‘Yesaṃ kesañci bhavasaṃyojanaṃ appahīnaṃ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:8.22.eng: You don’t say: ‘All those who have not given up the fetter of continued existence are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’

mn139:8.23.eng: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:

mn139:8.24.pli: ‘Bhavasaṃyojane ca kho appahīne bhavopi appahīno hotī’ti—
mn139:8.24.eng: ‘When the fetter of continued existence is not given up, continued existence is also not given up.’

mn139:8.26.pli: ‘Yesaṃ kesañci bhavasaṃyojanaṃ pahīnaṃ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
mn139:8.26.eng: You don’t say: ‘All those who have given up the fetter of continued existence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’

mn139:8.27.eng: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:

mn139:8.28.pli: ‘Bhavasaṃyojane ca kho pahīne bhavopi pahīno hotī’ti—
mn139:8.28.eng: ‘When the fetter of continued existence is given up, continued existence is also given up.’

mn139:8.30.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, nevussādanā hoti na apasādanā, dhammadesanā ca.
mn139:8.30.eng: That’s how there is neither flattering nor rebuking, and just teaching Dhamma.

mn139:8.31.eng: ‘Know what it means to flatter and to rebuke.

mn139:8.32.pli: ussādanañca ñatvā apasādanañca ñatvā nevussādeyya, na apasādeyya, dhammameva deseyyā’ti—
mn139:8.32.eng: Knowing these, avoid them, and just teach Dhamma.’

mn139:8.33.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn139:8.33.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn139:9.1.eng: ‘Know how to evaluate different kinds of pleasure.

mn139:9.3.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn139:9.3.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn139:9.4.eng: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn139:9.6.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
mn139:9.6.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn139:9.10.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā—
mn139:9.10.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn139:9.11.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn139:9.12.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ idaṃ vuccati kāmasukhaṃ mīḷhasukhaṃ puthujjanasukhaṃ anariyasukhaṃ.
mn139:9.12.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure—a filthy, common, ignoble pleasure.

mn139:9.13.pli: ‘Na āsevitabbaṃ, na bhāvetabbaṃ, na bahulīkātabbaṃ, bhāyitabbaṃ etassa sukhassā’ti—vadāmi.
mn139:9.13.eng: Such pleasure should not be cultivated or developed, but should be feared, I say.

mn139:9.14.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn139:9.14.eng: Now, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn139:9.15.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn139:9.15.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …

mn139:9.16.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe…

mn139:9.18.pli: Idaṃ vuccati nekkhammasukhaṃ pavivekasukhaṃ upasamasukhaṃ sambodhisukhaṃ.
mn139:9.18.eng: This is called the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening.

mn139:9.19.pli: ‘Āsevitabbaṃ, bhāvetabbaṃ, bahulīkātabbaṃ, na bhāyitabbaṃ etassa sukhassā’ti—vadāmi.
mn139:9.19.eng: Such pleasure should be cultivated and developed, and should not be feared, I say.

mn139:9.20.eng: ‘Know how to evaluate different kinds of pleasure.

mn139:9.22.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn139:9.22.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn139:10.1.pli: ‘Rahovādaṃ na bhāseyya, sammukhā na khīṇaṃ bhaṇe’ti—
mn139:10.1.eng: ‘Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.’

mn139:10.3.eng: but why did I say it?

mn139:10.4.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yaṃ jaññā rahovādaṃ abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ sasakkaṃ taṃ rahovādaṃ na bhāseyya.
mn139:10.4.eng: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is untrue, false, and pointless, then to the best of your ability you should not speak.

mn139:10.5.pli: Yampi jaññā rahovādaṃ bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ tassapi sikkheyya avacanāya.
mn139:10.5.eng: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is true and correct, but pointless, then you should train yourself not to speak.

mn139:10.6.pli: Yañca kho jaññā rahovādaṃ bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ tatra kālaññū assa tassa rahovādassa vacanāya.
mn139:10.6.eng: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is true, correct, and beneficial, then you should know the right time to speak.

mn139:10.7.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yaṃ jaññā sammukhā khīṇavādaṃ abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ sasakkaṃ taṃ sammukhā khīṇavādaṃ na bhāseyya.
mn139:10.7.eng: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are untrue, false, and pointless, then to the best of your ability you should not speak.

mn139:10.8.pli: Yampi jaññā sammukhā khīṇavādaṃ bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ tassapi sikkheyya avacanāya.
mn139:10.8.eng: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are true and correct, but pointless, then you should train yourself not to speak.

mn139:10.9.pli: Yañca kho jaññā sammukhā khīṇavādaṃ bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ tatra kālaññū assa tassa sammukhā khīṇavādassa vacanāya.
mn139:10.9.eng: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are true, correct, and beneficial, then you should know the right time to speak.

mn139:10.10.pli: ‘Rahovādaṃ na bhāseyya, sammukhā na khīṇaṃ bhaṇe’ti—
mn139:10.10.eng: ‘Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.’

mn139:10.11.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn139:10.11.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn139:11.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn139:11.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn139:11.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, taramānassa bhāsato kāyopi kilamati, cittampi upahaññati, saropi upahaññati, kaṇṭhopi āturīyati, avisaṭṭhampi hoti aviññeyyaṃ taramānassa bhāsitaṃ.
mn139:11.3.eng: When speaking hurriedly, your body gets tired, your mind gets stressed, your voice gets stressed, your throat gets sore, and your words become unclear and hard to understand.

mn139:11.4.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ataramānassa bhāsato kāyopi na kilamati, cittampi na upahaññati, saropi na upahaññati, kaṇṭhopi na āturīyati, visaṭṭhampi hoti viññeyyaṃ ataramānassa bhāsitaṃ.
mn139:11.4.eng: When not speaking hurriedly, your body doesn’t get tired, your mind doesn’t get stressed, your voice doesn’t get stressed, your throat doesn’t get sore, and your words are clear and easy to understand.

mn139:11.6.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn139:11.6.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn139:12.1.eng: ‘Don’t insist on popular definitions and don’t overstep normal labels.’

mn139:12.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn139:12.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn139:12.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, janapadaniruttiyā ca abhiniveso hoti samaññāya ca atisāro?
mn139:12.3.eng: And how do you insist on popular definitions and overstep normal labels?
mn139:12.3.comm: None of the terms below are regional or dialectical, so janapadanirutti means “expressions current among the people”, “popular terms”, “common vernacular” rather than “regional dialects”. | A Sanskrit fragment paralleling this passage lists various words for “person”, which likewise are not regional or dialectical terms (SHT ii 163aA3: (jīvo) vā jantur-vā (poṣo) vā pudgalo vā manujo).

mn139:12.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, tadevekaccesu janapadesu ‘pātī’ti sañjānanti, ‘pattan’ti sañjānanti, ‘vittan’ti sañjānanti, ‘sarāvan’ti sañjānanti ‘dhāropan’ti sañjānanti, ‘poṇan’ti sañjānanti, ‘pisīlavan’ti sañjānanti.
mn139:12.4.eng: It’s when among different populations they label the same thing as a ‘cup’, a ‘bowl’, a ‘jar’, a ‘scoop’, a ‘vessel’, a ‘dish’, or a ‘plate’.
mn139:12.4.comm: All these terms are either attested in Pali and/or Sanskrit or are readily explicable from Pali roots. This is not about “translating” the Dhamma wholesale, but about using different popular terms, as in the U.S. they refer to the same thing as “soda” or “pop”. | Pātī (“cup”) is from the root √pā, “to drink”, used in Pali for cups of bronze, gold, or silver. | Patta (“bowl”), the masculine form of the same root, is the standard word for a mendicant’s alms bowl. | For vittha (“jar”; variants vitta, piṭṭha) see vitthaka, a small jar for sewing gear (Kd 15:11.5.15). | Sarāva (“scoop”) is a common word for a scoop for water (eg. AN 3.57:3.2, Kd 15:14.3.30, Kv 1.1:356.6; Sanskrit śarāva, eg. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.1.4.12; Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.8.1; Manu 6.56; also in Jain texts). | For dhāropa (“vessel”) accept variant harosa by analogy with puṭosa (MN 118:8.9), yielding the sense “carrier for food”, “vessel”. | Poṇa (“dish”) is probably a concave dish with “sloped” sides (cp. English “hollowware”). | Pisīlava (“plate”) was used for the butter placed on the altar (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 2.5.3.6: piśīle vā pātryau vā).

mn139:12.5.pli: Iti yathā yathā naṃ tesu tesu janapadesu sañjānanti tathā tathā thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa voharati:
mn139:12.5.eng: And however it is known among those various populations, you speak accordingly, obstinately sticking to that and insisting:

mn139:12.6.eng: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’

mn139:12.7.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, janapadaniruttiyā ca abhiniveso hoti samaññāya ca atisāro.
mn139:12.7.eng: That’s how you insist on popular definitions and overstep normal labels.

mn139:12.8.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, janapadaniruttiyā ca anabhiniveso hoti samaññāya ca anatisāro?
mn139:12.8.eng: And how do you not insist on popular definitions and overstep normal labels?

mn139:12.9.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, tadevekaccesu janapadesu ‘pātī’ti sañjānanti, ‘pattan’ti sañjānanti, ‘vittan’ti sañjānanti, ‘sarāvan’ti sañjānanti, ‘dhāropan’ti sañjānanti, ‘poṇan’ti sañjānanti, ‘pisīlavan’ti sañjānanti.
mn139:12.9.eng: It’s when among different populations they label the same thing as a ‘cup’, a ‘bowl’, a ‘jar’, a ‘scoop’, a ‘vessel’, a ‘dish’, or a ‘plate’.

mn139:12.10.pli: Iti yathā yathā naṃ tesu tesu janapadesu sañjānanti ‘idaṃ kira me āyasmanto sandhāya voharantī’ti tathā tathā voharati aparāmasaṃ.
mn139:12.10.eng: And however it is known among those various populations, you speak accordingly, thinking: ‘It seems that the venerables are referring to this.’

mn139:12.11.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, janapadaniruttiyā ca anabhiniveso hoti, samaññāya ca anatisāro.
mn139:12.11.eng: That’s how you don’t insist on popular definitions and don’t overstep normal labels.

mn139:12.12.eng: ‘Don’t insist on popular definitions and don’t overstep normal labels.’
mn139:12.12.comm: This passage should be read with Kd 15:33.1.5. There, the Pali depicts the Buddha allowing individual glosses to terms (sakāya niruttiya).

mn139:12.13.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn139:12.13.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn139:13.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogo hīno gammo pothujjaniko anariyo anatthasaṃhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:13.1.eng: Now, mendicants, indulging in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:13.3.eng: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.

mn139:13.4.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṃ ananuyogo hīnaṃ gammaṃ pothujjanikaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
mn139:13.4.eng: Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.

mn139:13.6.eng: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.

mn139:13.7.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo attakilamathānuyogo dukkho anariyo anatthasaṃhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:13.7.eng: Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:13.9.eng: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.

mn139:13.10.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yo attakilamathānuyogaṃ ananuyogo dukkhaṃ anariyaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
mn139:13.10.eng: Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.

mn139:13.12.eng: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.

mn139:13.13.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yāyaṃ majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
mn139:13.13.eng: The middle way of practice that was understood by the Realized One gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment. It is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.

mn139:13.15.eng: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.

mn139:13.16.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yāyaṃ ussādanā ca apasādanā ca no ca dhammadesanā, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:13.16.eng: Flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:13.18.eng: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.

mn139:13.19.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yāyaṃ nevussādanā ca na apasādanā ca dhammadesanā ca, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
mn139:13.19.eng: Neither flattering nor rebuking, and just teaching Dhamma is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.

mn139:13.21.eng: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.

mn139:13.22.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ kāmasukhaṃ mīḷhasukhaṃ pothujjanasukhaṃ anariyasukhaṃ, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:13.22.eng: Sensual pleasure—a filthy, common, ignoble pleasure—is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:13.24.eng: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.

mn139:13.25.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ nekkhammasukhaṃ pavivekasukhaṃ upasamasukhaṃ sambodhisukhaṃ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
mn139:13.25.eng: The pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.

mn139:13.27.eng: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.

mn139:13.28.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ rahovādo abhūto ataccho anatthasaṃhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:13.28.eng: Saying untrue, false, and pointless things behind someone’s back is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:13.30.eng: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.

mn139:13.31.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ rahovādo bhūto taccho anatthasaṃhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:13.31.eng: Saying true and correct, but pointless things behind someone’s back is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:13.33.eng: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.

mn139:13.34.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ rahovādo bhūto taccho atthasaṃhito, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
mn139:13.34.eng: Saying true, correct, and beneficial things behind someone’s back is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.

mn139:13.36.eng: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.

mn139:13.37.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ sammukhā khīṇavādo abhūto ataccho anatthasaṃhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:13.37.eng: Saying untrue, false, and pointless things in someone’s presence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:13.39.eng: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.

mn139:13.40.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ sammukhā khīṇavādo bhūto taccho anatthasaṃhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:13.40.eng: Saying true and correct, but pointless things in someone’s presence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:13.42.eng: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.

mn139:13.43.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ sammukhā khīṇavādo bhūto taccho atthasaṃhito, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
mn139:13.43.eng: Saying true, correct, and beneficial things in someone’s presence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.

mn139:13.45.eng: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.

mn139:13.46.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ taramānassa bhāsitaṃ, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:13.46.eng: Speaking hurriedly is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:13.48.eng: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.

mn139:13.49.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ ataramānassa bhāsitaṃ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
mn139:13.49.eng: Speaking unhurriedly is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.

mn139:13.51.eng: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.

mn139:13.52.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ janapadaniruttiyā ca abhiniveso samaññāya ca atisāro, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho;
mn139:13.52.eng: Insisting on popular definitions and overriding common usage is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.

mn139:13.54.eng: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.

mn139:13.55.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṃ janapadaniruttiyā ca anabhiniveso samaññāya ca anatisāro, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho;
mn139:13.55.eng: Not insisting on popular definitions and not overriding common usage is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.

mn139:13.57.eng: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.

mn139:14.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘saraṇañca dhammaṃ jānissāma, araṇañca dhammaṃ jānissāma;
mn139:14.1.eng: So you should train like this: ‘We shall know the principles beset by strife and the principles free of strife.

mn139:14.2.pli: saraṇañca dhammaṃ ñatvā araṇañca dhammaṃ ñatvā araṇapaṭipadaṃ paṭipajjissāmā’ti evañhi vo, bhikkhave, sikkhitabbaṃ.
mn139:14.2.eng: Knowing this, we will practice the way free of strife.’

mn139:14.3.pli: Subhūti ca pana, bhikkhave, kulaputto araṇapaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno”ti.
mn139:14.3.eng: And, mendicants, the gentleman Subhūti practices the way free of strife.”
mn139:14.3.comm: This was apparently prompted by Subhūti’s support of his fellow monk Saddha at AN 11.14 , for which he was declared the foremost in living without strife (AN 1.201:1.1; he was additionally praised as worthy of donations (AN 1.202:1.1. Subhūti’s meditation is praised at Ud 6.7, and his verse opens the Theragāthā at Thag 1.1.

mn139:14.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn139:14.5.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn139:14.5.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
